subject: Communication
title: The Primacy-Recency Effect
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Primacy-Recency Effect.

hook.text: People remember the first thing you say and the last thing you say. Everything in the middle blurs.

buildup.text: The primacy effect means first impressions stick. The recency effect means endings linger longest.

discovery.text: Hermann Ebbinghaus proved this with memory experiments in the 1880s â€” and it holds for speeches too.

twist.text: Most speakers put their best material in the middle â€” exactly where the audience's attention dips.

climax.text: Smart speakers front-load their hook and save their strongest point for the final moment.

punchline.text: Open strong, close stronger. The middle is forgettable.

quiz.question: What does the primacy-recency effect predict about speeches?
options: Beginnings and endings are most memorable
